title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – The King found his crown in the Pacific Northwest, and in doing so, delivered a performance for the ages.

In a vintage display of sheer offensive mastery, Hakeem Olajuwon authored a historic night, pouring in a career-high 49 points to will the Houston Rockets to a 109-100 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

From the opening tip, this was the Olajuwon show. The Seattle defense, renowned for its toughness, had no answer for the Dream’s dizzying array of post moves, feathery touch from the baseline, and relentless pursuit of the basket. He was an unstoppable force, a whirlwind of fakes and spins that left defenders grasping at air. Each possession was a clinic, and each bucket chipped away at the Sonics’ resolve.

While Olajuwon’s singular brilliance dominated the narrative, he was not without a crucial supporting cast. Clyde Drexler, the other half of Houston’s veteran backbone, provided a vital 22-point counterpoint, while Eddie Johnson chipped in 18 off the bench. Their contributions were essential, but they were satellites orbiting a superstar sun.

For Seattle, the firepower was there but ultimately insufficient against the Olajuwon onslaught. Gary Payton paced the Sonics with 24 points, and Detlef Schrempf added a sturdy 20. Yet, on a night where a legend decided to rewrite the record books, their efforts were simply drowned out by the roar of one man’s greatness.

In the end, the final box score told the story: 49 points for Olajuwon, a number that would be etched into the record books and the memories of all who witnessed it. It was more than a win; it was a testament to a Hall of Fame career still capable of reaching breathtaking, unimaginable heights.
